qas.question: In what year was a Master of Arts course first offered at Notre Dame?
The granting of Doctorate degrees first occurred in what year at Notre Dame?
What type of degree is an M.Div.?
Which department at Notre Dame is the only one to not offer a PhD program?
Which program at Notre Dame offers a Master of Education degree?

context: The university first offered graduate degrees, in the form of a Master of Arts (MA), in the <a0_0>1854<a0_0/>–1855 academic year. The program expanded to include Master of Laws (LL.M.) and Master of Civil Engineering in its early stages of growth, before a formal graduate school education was developed with a thesis not required to receive the degrees. This changed in <a1_0>1924<a1_0/> with formal requirements developed for graduate degrees, including offering Doctorate (PhD) degrees. Today each of the five colleges offer graduate education. Most of the departments from the College of Arts and Letters offer PhD programs, while a professional <a2_0>Master of Divinity<a2_0/> (M.Div.) program also exists. All of the departments in the College of Science offer PhD programs, except for the <a3_0>Department of Pre-Professional Studies<a3_0/>. The School of Architecture offers a Master of Architecture, while each of the departments of the College of Engineering offer PhD programs. The College of Business offers multiple professional programs including MBA and Master of Science in Accountancy programs. It also operates facilities in Chicago and Cincinnati for its executive MBA program. Additionally, the <a4_0>Alliance for Catholic Education<a4_0/> program offers a Master of Education program where students study at the university during the summer and teach in Catholic elementary schools, middle schools, and high schools across the Southern United States for two school years.
